p.s: At the beginning, it is important to know, that Amir already was upset, before he found out, that his friend gets his job and his wife cheated on him.
Firstly, Isaac and Amir had an intense discussion about the Islam and his rules, where they both got aggressivaggressive.
Amir is drunk and just said he wants to make this evening special and wonderful and that they should stop talking about islamIslam (p. 68, l. 33-36).
But when he comes back into the room he is inflamed.
Amir was scared that his bosses avoidsavoid him and now he gets to know why.
Yet when Jory freaks out about Isaac and Emily Amir does not have the same reaction as her.
He does not recognize or understand it.
Even when Emily tries to explain it, he does not pay attention to it.
He doesn not give Emily the fault, but Jory.
He does not see what jsut happened, because he is so angry with Jory.
He acts like she would make the affair up (p. 72, l. 18-19).
With this words, his anger is shown very well, but it gets more intense after Jory does not pay attention to Amir's accusations.
At this point Amir explodes.
He still does not react to Jory's words about Isaac and Emily, but he wants to make her feel really bad about her taking his job or his place in the company.
He wants to make her feel like she does not deserve to have that job (p. 72, l. 27-28).
At one point he uses the N-word to really underline how unfair it is to ignore his hard work (p. 72, l. 29).
When Isaac offends Amir as an asshole he directly tells him back that he (Isaac) is the asshole.
The author's intention is to show Amir's fundamental anger and range.
This range has got higher than the moment before, where he did not pay attention to the cheating.
But after he exploded, he pays attention to everything.
After he freaks out at one time, he can't be stopped.
This can also be seen at p. 74, where he does not stop punching Emily, and is stuck in his range.
When Amir spits in Isaac's face, the author wants to underline how deep all of his background and anger is hidden in him.
Surely Amir was told by his mother to spit in people's faces or he has seen it because of her.
But he told Emily and Abe that this opened his eyes about Muslims and their prejudices, but he did it again, in a face of a grown jedishJewish man.
This point is the outburst and change point of the play.
Amir makes the reader believe how much he hates Islam and the things his mother thaughttaught him, but in this scene is able to see how much of the muslimMuslim prejudices is still stuck in him.
Isaac's words after the spit underlinesunderline that There is a reason they call you people animals (p. 73, l. 1), it is racist, but he clearly puts Amir and muslimsMuslims into one bag or drawer.
Indirectly he tells Amir, that he is still a muslimMuslim, because it is in him (p. 66, l. 37: It is in the bones).
Amir's action shows how aggressive he really is and of course the action where he hits Emily underlines that.
To make a conclusion or to come to an end, the picture of Amir changes in this scene, because he does something he swore wichwhich was horrible for him again.
He acts the same way his mother did and his anger is getting clearly here, and how the Islam is so much more a part of him the he thinks it is and probably more a part than he wants it to be.
He does not regret it, to spit in IsaacsIsaac's face, he only regrets that he hit Emily.
